Translation_en: You see something and then you laugh.
We don’t just laugh, right, aunt?
We laugh when somebody tells (us) something, something you see well, like that, right.
I don’t laugh, but they are saying “hahaha”.
Oh! You don’t get tired of laughing? I don’t laugh, is what I’m saying.
Yes indeed, they tell what they are doing there on the down-low.
They laugh because they tell it.
We’re not like that, we don’t just laugh.
What are we going to laugh about?
Nothing, there’s nothing for us to laugh.
That’s all I’m saying, too, I don’t know.
What are we going to laugh about?
I don’t laugh, I silently stay in my house.
Ugh, don’t you get tired from laughing so much?
I’m saying I am not happy.
I’m not like that, I don’t laugh.
I silently stay in my house.
We don’t see anything good, so we don’t laugh.
What they did, they’re going to tell.
So I won’t say any more.
Ugh, you are happy but I am not, I say.
Who are we gonna talk to? We’re alone, aunt.
Because we don’t have friends we don’t have anything to laugh.
When we’re alone, we don’t laugh.
What are we going to laugh about? Nothing.
Oh, there’s nothing to laugh about.
A man went there, far, to sleep.
He was staying in the dark and then went up high (in the house).
He went up high and then...
My urine hurts, I will urinate.
Then they said: “it’s raining, it’s raining”.
Then there was nothing of their vomit.
The chicha was gone and so was the vomit.
In the old house the mice were dancing.
Probably to the woods, dunno where they went.
Maybe they went to the woods.
I was here (in San Juan Manapiare).
We grew up when we were small.
We grew up, my uncle fished all of our food, lapa, picure.
My aunt was saying to my uncle: “go hunt, the children are hungry”.
Comment: 1) is it _yëmiri_? 2) is it a verb or a noun?

Translation_en: So the children don’t cry anymore.
All said, then my uncle went.
Comment: What is the function of *sukase ta wejsaj ta*?

Translation_en: He brought wolf fish, then (he said) here (it is).
“Sister, cook the children’s food”, she said.
My aunt said to my mother.
Our food, for us to eat.
Thus we grew up, after our father died in his village.
We all grew up with my younger brother, we grew up a little (?).
We grew up with my aunt.
She said to my uncle: “go hunt!”.
Because they (who?) were crying he went and got the dogs, to hunt agouti.
We all grew up like this, in a different way.
We were eating bitter manioc, then we drank yucuta.
After we ate chili, we drank yucuta.
That’s the way we grew up.
Then we grew up with him.
We became boys, my brother also became a man.
He raised us like (his own) children.
He didn’t beat us, we grew up well.
With this man we grew up.
We were with him for a long time.
Although I was with my mother, our house was a little further.
We were living in our house, that’s how we grew up.
In my late father’s old village.
